Indications and doses

Susceptible infections (e.g. chlamydia, rickettsia and mycoplasma),

By mouth

  • For adults
    Initially 200 mg daily for 1 dose, then 100 mg daily; 200 mg daily, increased dose used for severe infections including refractory urinary-tract infections.
  • For children 12–17 years
    Initially 200 mg daily for 1 dose, then 100 mg daily; 200 mg daily, increased dose used for severe infections including refractory urinary-tract infections.

Acne,

By mouth using immediate-release medicines

  • For adults
    100 mg daily.
  • For children 12–17 years
    100 mg daily.

Rosacea,

By mouth using immediate-release medicines

  • For adults
    100 mg daily.

Papulopustular facial rosacea (without ocular involvement),

By mouth using modified-release medicines

  • For adults
    40 mg once daily for 16 weeks, dose to be taken in the morning, consider discontinuing treatment if no response after 6 weeks.

Early syphilis,

By mouth using immediate-release medicines

  • For adults
    100 mg twice daily for 14 days.
  • For children 12–17 years
    100 mg twice daily for 14 days.

Late latent syphilis,

By mouth using immediate-release medicines

  • For adults
    100 mg twice daily for 28 days.
  • For children 12–17 years
    100 mg twice daily for 28 days.

Neurosyphilis,

By mouth using immediate-release medicines

  • For adults
    200 mg twice daily for 28 days.

Uncomplicated genital chlamydia, Non-gonococcal urethritis,

By mouth using immediate-release medicines

  • For adults
    100 mg twice daily for 7 days.
  • For children 12–17 years
    100 mg twice daily for 7 days.

Pelvic inflammatory disease,

By mouth using immediate-release medicines

  • For adults
    100 mg twice daily for 14 days.
  • For children 12–17 years
    100 mg twice daily for 14 days.

Lyme disease,

By mouth using immediate-release medicines

  • For adults
    100 mg twice daily for 10–14 days (for 28 days in Lyme arthritis).
  • For children 12–17 years
    100 mg twice daily for 10–14 days (for 28 days in Lyme arthritis).

Anthrax (treatment or post-exposure prophylaxis),

By mouth using immediate-release medicines

  • For adults
    100 mg twice daily.
  • For children 12–17 years
    100 mg twice daily.

Prophylaxis of malaria,

By mouth using immediate-release medicines

  • For adults
    100 mg once daily, to be started 1–2 days before entering endemic area and continued for 4 weeks after leaving, can be used for up to 2 years.
  • For children 12–17 years
    100 mg once daily, to be started 1–2 days before entering endemic area and continued for 4 weeks after leaving, can be used for up to 2 years.

Adjunct to quinine in treatment of Plasmodium falciparum malaria,

By mouth using immediate-release medicines

  • For adults
    200 mg daily for 7 days.
  • For children 12–17 years
    200 mg daily for 7 days.

Periodontitis (as an adjunct to gingival scaling and root planing),

By mouth using immediate-release medicines

  • For adults
    20 mg twice daily for 3 months.
  • For children 12–17 years
    20 mg twice daily for 3 months.

Treatment of recurrent aphthous ulceration,

By mouth using soluble tablets

  • For adults
    100 mg 4 times a day usually for 3 days, dispersible tablet can be stirred into a small amount of water then rinsed around the mouth for 2–3 minutes, it should preferably not be swallowed.
  • For children 12–17 years
    100 mg 4 times a day usually for 3 days, dispersible tablet can be stirred into a small amount of water then rinsed around the mouth for 2–3 minutes, it should preferably not be swallowed.

Advice when patient is pregnant

When travel to malarious areas is unavoidable during pregnancy, doxycycline can be used for malaria prophylaxis if other regimens are unsuitable, and if the entire course of doxycycline can be completed before 15 weeks’ gestation.

Advice regarding renal impairment

Use with caution (avoid excessive doses).

Known side effects

General side effects

notKnown: Anorexia, anxiety, dry mouth, flushing, fungal superinfection (when used for periodontitis), tinnitus,

Directions for administration

Capsules and Tablets should be swallowed whole with plenty of fluid, while sitting or standing. Capsules should be taken during meals.

Advice for patients and carers

Counselling on administration advised (posture).

Photosensitivity

Patients should be advised to avoid exposure to sunlight or sun lamps.

Cautions regarding administration

  • Alcohol dependence

Monitoring requirements

Patient parameters

When used for periodontitis, monitor for superficial fungal infection, particularly if predisposition to oral candidiasis.

Unlicensed use

In children

Not licensed for use in children under 12 years.

Doxycycline doses in BNF Publications may differ from those in product literature.

Not licensed for severe recurrent aphthous ulceration.

Not licensed for malaria prophylaxis during pregnancy.

In adults

Immediate-release doxycycline not licensed for treatment of rosacea.

Profession specific information

Dental practitioners

Doxycycline Capsules 100 mg may be prescribed.

Dispersible tablets may be prescribed as Dispersible Doxycycline Tablets.

Tablets may be prescribed as Doxycycline Tablets 20 mg.

Prepared medicinal forms of DOXYCYCLINE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: oral suspension, oral solution,
